header.title: How to develop with Simal
header.abstract: This How-To describes how to set up your development envirnment for working with Simal. Since Simal uses many Eclipse plugins in components of the Simal project it makes most sense for you to work within the Eclipse environment (although this is not a requirement, it just makes your life easier). This how-to therefore focuses on configuring Eclipse for working on Simal.

audience.title: Intended Audience
audience.p: People wishing to participate in the development of Simal.

purpose.title: Purpose
purpose.p: To identify the ideal development environment for working with Simal.

ul.li: Have at least a basic understanding of XML, XSLT and Java
Have at least a basic understanding of Java development in Eclipse

section.title: Eclipse 3.2 + Web Tools Project 1.5
section.p: Download and unpack the Eclipse + WTP.

section.title: Apache Derby
section.p: Download the Derby Core and Derby UI Plugins Derby downlaods page and unpack them into your Eclipse directory.

section.title: Dali
section.p: Download Dali and unpack it in the Eclipse directory created in the previous section.

section.title: Subclipse
section.p: We use a Subversion repository for our source code, therefore you need the subclipse plugins for working with the repository. Follow these simple steps:
In the Eclipse menu select Help -> Software Updates -> Find and Install...
In the resulting dialog select Search for new features to install then click next
Click New Remote Site...
Enter a Name of Subclipse and and URL of http://subclipse.tigris.org/update_1.2.x and click Finish
After a short delay whilst the update site is searched you will be able to expand the subclipse node and select subclipse for download.
[OPTIONAL] You may also choose to install the Mylar Integration plugin at this time. Mylar is not required, but is one of the optional plugins we will discuss later in this document.
Click Next
Agree to the license terms (assuming you do agree that is) and click Next
Review the plugins you have selected and click Finish
After the plugins are downloaded click the Install All button
Restart Eclipse when asked to do so

section.title: Get Simal Sources
section.p: The first thing you need to do is checkout the Simal source code. To do this use the simal.psf team set.
Save the simal.psf file in a convenient location
In Eclipse select File -> Import
In the dialog select Team -> Team Project Set and click Next
Select the simal.psf file you saved earlier and click Finish
After following these steps the source code for Simal will be checked out from version control, ready for you to start work.

section.title: Get Rich Ajax Platform Sources
section.p: At the time of writing we are using the CVS head version of the Eclipse Rich Ajax Platform. It is expected that, in the future, we will use a stable release of this code, but at present we need some features only available in CVS head. Follow the instructions on the Eclipse RAP site.

section.title: Test Setup So Far
section.fixme: The simal configuration described in this section is not brought across as part of the import, neither is the model.test plugin.
section.p: During development we use an embedded Apache Derby database. This enables you to do development work independently of any production database. The first thing you need to do is start the databse server. to do this right click on the uk.ac.osswatch.simal.model.test project and select Apache Derby -> Start Network Server.

Now you should now be able to run the Simal web application. Open the Run wizard by selecting Run --> Run from the Eclipse menu. In the wizard choose Equinox OSGi Framework -> Simal RAP (Test Database) and after that click run. Some messages in the console view should indicate that the http service was started at port 100080. Now open a browser and type navigate to http://localhost:100080/rap to access the Simal application.
